dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The stock market just took a brutal hit this Wednesday, with the S&P 500 dropping 1.1% and the Dow plunging nearly 500 points.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The stock market just took a brutal hit this Wednesday, with the S&P five hundred dropping one point one percent and the Dow plunging nearly five hundred points.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 index rose 1.1% on Wednesday, hitting a new record closing high of 3334.69 and fully erasing its losses stemming from fears over the coronavirus and its impact on businesses and the global economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped nearly 500 points, gaining 1.7% and putting the index back within reach of its pre-coronavirus levels.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that's, uh, the third day of losses in a row for all three major indexes—really wiping out a lot of the gains from earlier this year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's, uh, the third day of losses in a row for all three major indexes-really wiping out a lot of the gains from earlier this year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All three major indexes have now posted gains for the third day in a row, marking a recovery from a huge sell-off on coronavirus fears last Friday when the Dow shed 600 points and posted its worst single-day drop since August 2019, while the S&P 500 saw its largest decline since October.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And it's interesting because, um, the Nasdaq actually went against the trend—it gained 2.4%, largely thanks to Tesla.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And it's interesting because, um, the Nasdaq actually went against the trend-it gained two point four percent, largely thanks to Tesla.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Nasdaq Composite index, on the other hand, lagged both the Dow and S&P 500, gaining only 0.4%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, Tesla shares surged almost 20% on Wednesday after reports that coronavirus wouldn't affect its Shanghai factory production.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, Tesla shares surged almost twenty percent on Wednesday after reports that coronavirus wouldn't affect its Shanghai factory production.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Nasdaq was held back in large part because Tesla shares, which soared up to 50% earlier this week, plunged by almost 20% on Wednesdayits worst day everamid reports that the coronavirus would impact production and deliveries at its factory in Shanghai, China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But even with that jump, Tesla is still down more than 70% for 2020 so far, which is just staggering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But even with that jump, Tesla is still down more than seventy percent for twenty twenty so far, which is just staggering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even with Wednesdays record plunge, Tesla stock is still up more than 70% in 2020.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's that ADP and Moody's Analytics report—private payrolls decreased by 291,000 in January, which is the biggest monthly loss in almost five years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's that A D P and Moody's Analytics report-private payrolls decreased by two hundred ninety one thousand in January, which is the biggest monthly loss in almost five years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Adding to the good news for the market on Wednesday was a report from ADP and Moodys Analytics, which said that U.S. private payrolls rose by 291,000 in Januaryalmost twice the expected number and the biggest monthly payroll gain in almost five years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That's a huge miss from expectations, and it really adds to the sense that investors are spooked by both the virus and economic signals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a huge miss from expectations, and it really adds to the sense that investors are spooked by both the virus and economic signals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And you know, Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge called it—the bearish narrative is back in control after a brief pause late last month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And you know, Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge called it-the bearish narrative is back in control after a brief pause late last month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The bullish narrative thats been driving stocks since late 2019 is firmly back in control of the tape after taking a brief pause during the final days of January.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It feels like everything's compounding: coronavirus fears, disappointing earnings, maybe even overvaluation concerns.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels like everything's compounding: coronavirus fears, disappointing earnings, maybe even overvaluation concerns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But he also predicted, um, that the work stoppages and travel bans might not actually have a material impact on global growth long-term.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But he also predicted, um, that the work stoppages and travel bans might not actually have a material impact on global growth long-term.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The coronavirus-linked work stoppages and travel restrictions will have a material impact on global growth, Crisafulli recently predicted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, with the S&P now negative for 2020 and the Nasdaq down over 4%, it's clear investors aren't taking any chances.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, with the S&P now negative for twenty twenty and the Nasdaq down over four percent, it's clear investors aren't taking any chances.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 has now fully recovered from its coronavirus-related losses, turning positive for 2020 so far. The best-performing index so far is the Nasdaq, however, thanks to its 4.1% rise in 2020.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And after that huge sell-off last Friday, it's like whiplash—up 600 points one day, down 500 the next.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And after that huge sell-off last Friday, it's like whiplash-up six hundred points one day, down five hundred the next.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped nearly 500 points, gaining 1.7% and putting the index back within reach of its pre-coronavirus levels.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It just shows how fragile sentiment is right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It just shows how fragile sentiment is right now.

HostB: Yeah, and that’s, uh, the third day of losses in a row for all three major indexes—really wiping out a lot of the gains from earlier this year.
HostA: Exactly. And it’s interesting because, um, the Nasdaq actually went against the trend—it gained 2.4%, largely thanks to Tesla.
HostB: Right, Tesla shares surged almost 20% on Wednesday after reports that coronavirus wouldn’t affect its Shanghai factory production.
HostA: But even with that jump, Tesla is still down more than 70% for 2020 so far, which is just staggering.
HostB: And then there’s that ADP and Moody’s Analytics report—private payrolls decreased by 291,000 in January, which is the biggest monthly loss in almost five years.
HostA: That’s a huge miss from expectations, and it really adds to the sense that investors are spooked by both the virus and economic signals.
HostB: And you know, Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge called it—the bearish narrative is back in control after a brief pause late last month.
HostA: It feels like everything’s compounding: coronavirus fears, disappointing earnings, maybe even overvaluation concerns.
HostB: But he also predicted, um, that the work stoppages and travel bans might not actually have a material impact on global growth long-term.
HostA: Still, with the S&P now negative for 2020 and the Nasdaq down over 4%, it’s clear investors aren’t taking any chances.
HostB: For sure. And after that huge sell-off last Friday, it’s like whiplash—up 600 points one day, down 500 the next.
HostA: Exactly. It just shows how fragile sentiment is right now.
